title: British Columbia's Flooding Is Worse Because of Climate Change
description: After a summer of deadly heat and uncontrolled wildfires, British Columbia was hit by record rainfalls that forced the evacuation of towns and destroyed highways and rail lines.

title: In Hard Times, Afghan Farmers Are Turning to Opium for Security
description: The war’s intense conclusion and a drought combined to wipe out the famous Afghan pomegranate harvest in Kandahar Province, during a devastating national economic crisis.

title: Chileans Will Vote For President on Sunday
description: The top contenders to lead Chile out of a turbulent era are a leftist 35-year-old former student activist and a 55-year-old far-right former congressman, offering voters a stark choice.

title: Ousted in Coup, Sudan’s Prime Minister Returns via Military Deal
description: Four weeks after he was detained, Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok struck a deal to end a bloody standoff in the streets. Protesters rejected the move as a “betrayal.”

title: Israeli Is Killed by Palestinian Near Holiest Site in Jerusalem
description: The shooting, the first attack by a Palestinian since May to result in the death of a Jewish civilian, could deepen tensions within Israel’s fragile governing coalition.

title: As Pandemic Evictions Rise, Spaniards Declare ‘War’ on Wall Street Landlords
description: Protesters in Barcelona are pushing back against foreign investment firms that have bought up thousands of homes over the past decade and are forcing out residents who can’t pay the rent.

title: Myanmar's Notorious Army Is Facing a Morale Crisis
description: The number of defectors, while not enough to topple the Tatmadaw, is growing, galvanized by the nationwide anti-coup movement.

title: Peng Shuai Said to Be in Videos From China's State Media
description: The editor of a state-run newspaper on Saturday shared clips said to be of the Chinese tennis star on Twitter. But they are unverified, and the head of the WTA called them “insufficient.”

title: How India's Farmers Got Narendra Modi to Back Down
description: They received foreign and domestic financial support, kept their camps organized and looked for ways to be seen while trying to avoid violence.

title: Rolling Deep: South Korean Youth Roam the City in Hair Curlers
description: The young South Korean women who wear them say they are not only functional, but also a sign of shifting ideas about beauty and a reflection of the country’s generational divide.

title: A Socialite, a Gardener, a Message in Blood: The Murder That Still Grips France
description: The victim was a socialite. A message in her blood accused the gardener. But a grammatical error raised questions of class and language — and whether he was being framed.

title: In South Sudan, Vaccines Are Overshadowed by Pressing Needs
description: Much of South Sudan is under water from flooding induced by climate change and deforestation. Crops and livestock are lost, hunger and malaria are spreading. With so many worries, coronavirus vaccines are a tough sell.

title: The Daily Mail's Top Editor is Out. What Could It Mean for the U.K.?
description: The top editor is out at The Daily Mail, widely viewed as the voice of middle-class voters, and the paper’s coverage of Boris Johnson’s government might be softened because of it.

title: Thousands in Austria Protest Covid Lockdown and Vaccine Mandate
description: The protests were largely peaceful, but as dusk fell over the Austrian capital, skirmishes broke out between officers and groups of demonstrators.

title: Playwright Is in Exile as Cuba Uses an Old Playbook to Quash Dissent
description: Yunior García, one of the rising stars of the Cuban protest movement, fled to Spain. He is one of a young generation of artists who say they have chosen exile over imprisonment.

title: Ardeshir Zahedi, Irrepressible Iranian Diplomat, Dies at 93
description: While he enabled business deals worth billions of dollars, he also hosted lavish parties, led conga lines through his embassy and dated Elizabeth Taylor.

title: Michigan Hospitals Struggle With Covid Surge
description: Staffing shortages and pandemic fatigue add to complications.

title: More Asian Countries Slowly Reopen to Fully Vaccinated Travelers
description: The easing of restrictions comes as the holiday travel season is about to begin.

title: How the U.S. Lost Ground to China in the Contest for Clean Energy
description: Americans failed to safeguard decades of diplomatic and financial investments in Congo, where the world’s largest supply of cobalt is controlled by Chinese companies backed by Beijing.

title: Who, and Where, Is Chinese Tennis Star Peng Shuai?
description: A blackout within China on discussion of the tennis star’s #MeToo allegations has not been able to silence a global chorus of concern for her safety.

title: A Canadian senator has died after being hospitalized for Covid.
Just a few storms cloud the U.S. travel forecast for a second pandemic Thanksgiving.
Italy Braces for Protests Over Country’s Covid Health Pass
description: A skimpy turnout for a rally in Rome and the outright failure of one in Milan underscored Italians’ overall acceptance of the country’s Green Pass.

title: Singapore Will Start Easing Its Covid Rules Next Week
description: The Southeast Asian city state is recovering from a recent surge of hospitalizations. An official said its reopening would proceed in a “step-by-step manner.”

title: What to Know About the Frantic Quest for Cobalt
description: A New York Times investigation examines the global demand for raw materials as the clean energy revolution takes off. This is what we found.

title: A Power Struggle Over Cobalt Rattles the Clean Energy Revolution
description: The quest for Congo’s cobalt, which is vital for electric vehicles and the worldwide push against climate change, is caught in an international cycle of exploitation, greed and gamesmanship.

title: Beavers Misbehave. Canadians Love Them Anyway.
description: Blamed for flooded fields, damaged roads and the occasional death, the beaver, which has played a seminal role in Canadian history, is now viewed by many as a problem, not a point of national pride.

title: How Hunter Biden’s Firm Helped Secure Cobalt for the Chinese
description: The president’s son was part owner of a venture involved in the $3.8 billion purchase by a Chinese conglomerate of one of the world’s largest cobalt deposits. The metal is a key ingredient in batteries for electric vehicles.

title: Protesters in Australia Rally Against Covid Restrictions
description: Demonstrators gathered in cities around the country to protest vaccine mandates and other rules.

title: Canada Keeps World Cup Dream Alive in Qualifying Match
description: The Canadian men’s team, which has not been in the World Cup since 1986, is now leading the regional qualifying competition.

title: Canada Expands Vaccines Accepted for Travel
description: Officials also removed a test requirement for eligible travelers re-entering Canada within 72 hours.

title: Amazon Deforestation Soars to 15-Year High
description: Brazil committed this month to end illegal deforestation in eight years, but a government report raises questions about its intent and ability to meet that target.

title: On Putin’s Strategic Chessboard, a Series of Destabilizing Moves
description: In the stretch of Europe from the Baltic Sea to the Black Sea, where Moscow and the West have competed for influence for decades, the threat of a new military conflict is growing.

title: Austria Announces Covid Vaccine Mandate, Crossing a Threshold for Europe
description: The extraordinary step shows that governments desperate to safeguard public health and economic recoveries are increasingly willing to push for once unthinkable measures.

title: Canada Approves Pfizer's Covid Vaccine for Kids 5 to 11
description: The move adds more than 2.8 million young people to those eligible for a shot.

title: Venezuelan Opposition Risks an Election Challenge to Maduro
description: With little hope of a fair vote, opposition candidates take a desperate risk to gain any edge against Venezuela’s entrenched autocrat, Nicolás Maduro.

title: China’s Influence Looms Over Blinken’s Africa Visit
description: On a stop in Nigeria, the secretary of state said the U.S. would no longer treat African countries as pawns in a global game. But American competition with Beijing was hard to overlook.

title: German Health Minister Won't Rule Out New Lockdown
description: The remarks came in response to a reporter’s question as neighboring Austria prepares to lock down and cases continue to reach record levels.

title: Why the U.S. Is Considering Expanding Booster Shot Eligibility to All Adults
description: The U.S. may soon offer booster shots to every adult. Here’s why.

title: Japan Approves a $490 Billion Stimulus Package
description: The move, announced on Friday, is an attempt by the country’s newish prime minister to revive an economy battered by Covid restrictions and a supply chain crunch.

title: After Time in U.S. Prisons, Maria Butina Now Sits in Russia's Parliament
description: Maria Butina, convicted of serving as an unregistered foreign agent before and after the 2016 election, insists she “wasn’t a spy” and that her Duma seat is “not a reward.” Her critics call her a Kremlin “trophy.”

title: 1946: U.K. Launches Campaign for Roosevelt Statue
description: Prime Minister Clement Attlee announced a fund-raising drive to erect a statue of Franklin D. Roosevelt opposite the American embassy in London.

title: What Does Mateship Mean to You?
description: It’s a complicated, often-contested word that has evolved along with Australia’s values.

title: In Welcoming Prince Charles, Egypt’s Leader Sends a Message
description: The prince and his wife, Camilla, made Egypt their first foreign destination since the pandemic. Vestiges of British colonialism aside, they saw something new.

title: China and U.S. Quietly Released Captive Citizens Before Summit
description: The moves seemed aimed at untangling diplomatic knots as the two countries are clashing over human rights abuses, economic policies and much more.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Tensions ease at the Poland-Belarus border.

title: Modi to Repeal India Farm Laws Following Protests
description: A bungled response to Covid and a struggling economy have hurt his party’s standing, leaving it vulnerable to a well-organized protest movement.

title: Cambodia Reopens for Fully Vaccinated Travelers
description: Tourism-dependent businesses have struggled to make ends meet without visitors.

title: Strike on U.S. Base Was Iranian Response to Israeli Attack, Officials Say
description: Iran has not acknowledged the attack, but U.S. and Israeli officials said it was retaliation for Israeli airstrikes, drawing the U.S. into Iran’s shadow war with Israel.

title: The U.S. Army secretary to National Guard members who resist the vaccines: Prepare for discipline.
description: Remaining unvaccinated could cost soldiers promotions, bonuses or even their jobs.

title: Belarus Clears Migrant Camp, Easing Border Standoff With Poland
description: Throngs of people, mainly from the Mideast, who had been living in freezing conditions on the border, have been moved to a giant warehouse. Their fate is uncertain.

title: Greece, Facing Surging Cases, Adds Restrictions for the Unvaccinated
description: Germany restricts access to public transportation, Austria will impose full lockdowns in two states, and the Netherlands recently restored mask mandates in some public indoor places.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Where do the migrants in Belarus go next?
